{"step_by_step_thinking": "Document [0] suggests that healthy lifestyles lead to an increase in the utilization of preventive health services, but there is not much significant reduction in the number of outpatient visits in people with health behaviors. Document [3] suggests that individuals with targeted health conditions improved their lifestyle behaviors, which reduced smoking. Document [14] suggests that seniors who were leaner, smoked fewer cigarettes over a lifetime, reduced their smoking, or walked farther had significant subsequent cost savings compared to those with less-healthy lifestyle-related habits. Document [16] suggests that health promotion works to enhance individual autonomy and can reduce medical need and demand. Document [22] suggests that the real question, especially for developing countries, is 'what is the future healthcare cost of not encouraging healthier lifestyles today?'. Document [28] suggests that the HLHP strategy cost corresponded to 5.6% of the annual healthcare expenditures attributable to lifestyle-related risk factors. Document [30] suggests that human behavior sits on the final common pathway to so many of our health and health care goals, including the prevention and management of illness and the fostering of wellness. Based on these documents, it seems that healthier lifestyles can lead to less utilization of healthcare resources, but it's not a straightforward relationship and depends on various factors.", "answer_choice": "C. maybe"}
